sf276:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Śrāvastī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍada’s monastery.
sf276:2.1: Now at that time, the whole disk of the moon had been held captive by the demon-lord Rāhu.
sf276:3.1: Then, the deity who lived in the moon, who was afraid, terrified, shocked and awestruck, approached the Buddha. Having approached and worshiped the Buddha’s feet with his head, he stood to one side. Standing to one side, the deity addressed the Buddha in verse:
sf276:4.1: Homage to you Buddha, the hero, freed in every way.
sf276:4.2: I’m in a difficult situation, so be my refuge.
sf276:5.1: The moon has gone for refuge to the perfected one, the Holy One in the World,
sf276:5.2: and Buddhas have compassion for the world, so Rāhu will release the Month!
sf276:7.1: The moon dispels the darkness, it is a giver of light which shines in the heavens, with pure bright rays,
sf276:7.2: but Rāhu has eclipsed the Hare Marked One in the sky, that light of humanity. Rāhu, release the moon at once!
sf276:8.1: Then the disk of the moon was let go in a hurry by the demon-lord Rāhu.
sf276:8.2: Due to the spell, Rāhu let the moon go in a rush,
sf276:8.3: his body was drenched in sweat; he was distressed and bewildered, and he looked unwell.
sf276:9.1: Baḍi Vairocana saw that the disk of the moon was let go in a hurry by the demon-lord Rāhu. Seeing this, Baḍi addressed him in verse:
sf276:10.1: Rāhu, why did you set the moon free in a rush,
sf276:10.2: with your body drenched in sweat; distressed and bewildered, and looking unwell?
sf276:12.1: My head would have exploded in seven pieces, I would have had no happiness for the rest of my life,
sf276:12.2: if while under the spell of the Buddha, I did not release the One with a Hare.
sf276:13.2: x x x x x - - - x x x x of those who see.
sf276:13.3: This is how Rāhu freed the moon because of a spell.
